head.title: A Homeless Shelter in Search of a Home of Its Own

identified-content.org: Grand Central Neighborhood Social Services Corp

hedline.hl1: A Homeless Shelter in Search of a Home of Its Own

abstract.p: Homeless shelter run by Grand Central Neighborhood Social Services Corp, largest drop-in shelter in New York City, is notified that it must move from basement of Church of St Agnes, where it moved on temporary basis last year; photo (M)

block.p: The city's largest drop-in shelter for the homeless is itself on the brink of homelessness.

The shelter is run by the Grand Central Neighborhood Social Services Corporation. For more than a year, it has operated from the basement of the Church of St. Agnes on East 43rd Street between Lexington and Third Avenues, near Grand Central Terminal.
The city's largest drop-in shelter for the homeless is itself on the brink of homelessness.

The shelter is run by the Grand Central Neighborhood Social Services Corporation. For more than a year, it has operated from the basement of the Church of St. Agnes on East 43rd Street between Lexington and Third Avenues, near Grand Central Terminal.
But last week, Msgr. Eugene V. Clark, pastor of the church, returned the shelter's $1,729 rent check, causing shelter officials to wonder if they would be forced onto the street.
''We don't know what's going to happen to us,'' said Jeff Grunberg, executive director of the corporation. ''We're hoping that we'll find a space.''
Although the church would like to reclaim its basement, which is used as a lecture hall, Monsignor Clark said Mr. Grunberg's fears were unfounded.

''We've taken no action, and we've threatened no action,'' Monsignor Clark said. ''Obviously, they're not going to leave until they find a place, and we understand that. We're going to be as patient as possible.''

The 24-hour drop-in shelter, which serves 200 people a day, opened in 1989 as part of the city's effort to combat homelessness in the area around Grand Central Terminal. It was originally housed in the church's school a block away on 44th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues, but was evicted last year when the school was sold to a developer for luxury housing. At that point, the church agreed to house the shelter in its basement temporarily.
Monsignor Clark said he refused to accept the shelter's rent check because the church had no contract with the shelter for use of the basement.

Mr. Grunberg has been looking for a year for a permanent home. His likeliest option is a building at 34th Street near Lexington Avenue. But residents and business owners in the neighborhood say the shelter is unwelcome.

''We have more social services than any other community board in the city of New York,'' said Linda Nevins, vice president of the Rosehill Community Association, a local group. ''I think it's too much for our community to absorb. We've done our fair share.''
The area is home to eight medical institutions, two homeless shelters and nine methadone clinics. Residents fear that another shelter would increase the numbers of homeless.
''We know we could help that neighborhood a lot,'' he said.
